instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message: i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> it had water damage  i get 20v with 19milliamps i have a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> can you help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
20V on USB-C input without <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
That's really strange.
Did you test disconnecting battery?
Are you using original charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
yes I disconnected  the  battery and i get 
3.4v from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 0.086v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message: what is the best way to find the short on ppbus _g3h

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
Sorry, I was thinking to <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, instead of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Check if any big coil gives the same value to ground as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message: nothing should i run some voltage throw ppbus to get short hot if so how much voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
0.086 is not very low value.
But you can try injecting voltage; may have luck and some chip enter in thermal avalanche.
Start with low voltage and slowly increase, monitoring the temps; IR cam can help a lot.

Be absolutely sure no high-side MOSFET is shorted.
Check on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
it was <CAPACITOR>C7421</CAPACITOR> that was short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL>
I DON,T HAVE THAT CAP BUT IT IS WORKING WITH OUT IT CAN I LEAVE IT LIKE THIS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
These 33uF caps work like energy reservoir for iGPU power supply.
May be important under high graphics load...
